**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not developed many differences. Genetically, we are still more than 98% similar to chimps. This means that the differences between humans and animals are very recent. Our biological history suggests that our ability to create art and other unique human traits come from just a small part of our genes. This is a big responsibility for a few genes.
Recent studies of animal behavior show that many traits once thought to be unique to humans are now seen as differences in degree. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language, with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings suggest that there are not many absolute differences between humans and animals, except for art.
If human art comes from a unique genetic trait, it is strange that our ancestors did not create art for almost 6.9 million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art may have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. The first clear evidence of human art appears around 35,000 years ago with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.
If we believe that our recent artistic explosion makes us different, we need to consider how our art is different from that of animals. Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it is created for beauty, and it is learned rather than instinctive.
First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. While some human art communicates ideas to others, this is not the same as passing on genes. In contrast, birdsong serves clear purposes, like defending territory or attracting a mate, which helps them pass on their genes. By this standard, human art does seem different.
The second claim is that human art is motivated by a desire for beauty. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mainly sing during the breeding season, suggesting they do not sing just for beauty. Again, this makes human art seem unique.
The third claim is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from those in Paris. However, these differences are not in the singers' genes. People from different cultures can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' songs, even if they have never heard them before.
The role of learning in human art is also clear because our art styles change quickly. For example, geese have made the same sounds for 2,000 years, but human art evolves rapidly. Even casual museum visitors can tell that a painting from the twentieth century is newer than the Mona Lisa. Art experts can often identify when a painting was made and who created it.
Interestingly, two chimpanzees named Congo and Betsy created paintings that some people might mistake for human art. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day, seemingly for his own enjoyment. In 1957, they had an exhibition of their work in London, and many of their paintings sold, which is something many human artists cannot achieve.
These chimpanzee paintings challenge the idea that human art is completely different from animal behavior. Like human art, the paintings made by apes were not created for practical purposes; they were made for the satisfaction of the painter. Some might argue that human art is different because it is often meant to communicate with others, while the apes did not care about sharing their work. However, even some famous human art was created for personal satisfaction rather than communication.

An Amazing Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth. It is also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the story. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to be about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes focused on distant horizons during their journeys into the unknown. Nowadays, you rarely find such characters in stories or in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's great adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert. Its name means "once entered, you never come out," but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that incredible journey while at home with his family. The team included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It later turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have endangered everyone’s lives and the success of the expedition.
This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the world's harshest deserts, and Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to discover who he really was outside the Army. "I had always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I had been offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who I was outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn’t come back since nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was surprisingly good to us."
Anyone reading his amazing story will wonder why he used the word "good." The team faced terrible challenges: sickness, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and losing part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we managed to find some. We didn’t experience the desert's famous sandstorms, and we never faced the freezing cold that could have stopped us completely. That doesn’t mean we didn’t struggle the whole time. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and for the heavily loaded camels, which often fell over onto us."
"What pushed me on more than anything was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn’t allow for one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared about my physical ability to do it. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do it now!' At that moment, I was very scared."
If it was tough at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking for 1,000 kilometers, you’re not going to give up. You’ve endured so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but also very strong despite our exhaustion. My body was fit, and my legs felt powerful. I could walk over anything."
Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon and thinking of his family. How aware was he of how hard it must have been for them? "Inside me, there’s someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the image of the desert and remember that we managed to complete that journey. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I’ve done. Yet, when I think of my life’s achievements, I think of my family and the happiness we share — by that measure, the desert does not compare."
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge — for the open spaces — the excitement of it all. We were lifted by our sense of purpose. I find it hard now to fit into the sameness of modern life."

Life was getting out of control for Susan Harr, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us amazing devices that make life easier and give us more free time. However, this belief has made us think that technology is the best way to live. Using our fingers does not use up energy like machines do, and doing things by hand does not harm the environment. 
Recently, Susan had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which cost her a lot of money to fix. This made her question whether gadgets are really worth the cost and trouble. She started to let her household gadgets break down naturally. This made her think about what "free time" really means. Does it just mean we have more time to buy more gadgets? If that’s true, then the marketing experts are tricking us.
When her broken gadget started making strange noises, even when it was unplugged, she left it outside, where it now sits quietly. She enjoys not being tied to noisy machines and can take her time with her sewing. She was always a bit scared of electric machines that move quickly near her fingers. 
There are some gadgets she still values, like her washing machine, which she missed after a year without it. But losing some gadgets has made her happier. She felt that her family was spending too much time in front of the TV, so she returned their rented color TV and got a small black-and-white one instead. This change helped them spend more time walking their dog, reading, talking, and enjoying other hobbies. 
One of her hobbies is sewing, but her old sewing machine is now just a table for plants. Since she cannot afford a new one, she has started sewing by hand. People often think they cannot live without their gadgets, but Susan believes that life can be better without them. She feels sorry for those who had to do hard work without machines. 
Computers make our lives easier by doing fast calculations and providing entertainment. However, the time she spends sewing is enjoyable, and she can listen to the radio or talk with family while she works. If the task is simple, she can even watch TV without feeling guilty because she is also being productive. 
Sewing by the fire with a cup of tea feels cozy. She used to think that women who sewed by hand had a hard life, but now she finds it relaxing and satisfying. Watching her work become neater makes her happy. She realizes that things can be done quickly, and she can slow down her life to match her own pace. 
She also enjoys washing dishes by hand, which allows her to daydream. Now, she looks around her house and wonders if they really need things like a freezer, microwave, or electric lawnmower. She thinks they could save a lot of money by living without electric lights!

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who makes a living by creating beautifully crafted furniture. Joanna Watt meets him in his workshop, which is located under a railway arch in East London. When I arrive, he greets me with a quick handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" It is not clear if he is really in a hurry or just acting tough. Looking around the workshop, I can see that Hurst is busy. The space is filled with unfinished furniture and pieces of wood in many natural colors.
Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has a great reputation. His order book is always full for several months ahead, even though he does not advertise himself. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the right person to contact. 
Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one who makes high-quality furniture with clean, simple designs is more difficult. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many people call themselves furniture-makers." He is often disappointed by the quality of modern furniture. "I am amazed by what some furniture-makers get away with, and saddened by what people will accept," he says. Hurst is critical of poorly made, mass-produced furniture and craftsmen who create low-quality pieces. His desire for perfection is a big part of his success, along with his talent.
Hurst is confident about his skills. He says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He is self-taught and learned his craft by asking questions and observing. Most of his work comes from private clients, and some return to him for more projects. "You end up doing the whole of their house. That is very satisfying," he explains. However, he admits that not all client relationships are easy. "The most frustrating clients are those who don’t know what they want and change their minds too late. My favorite clients are the exacting ones."
Although Hurst is proud of his work, he also respects others who are skilled. He says, "There are people far better than me. I can admire other people." He criticizes craftsmen who try to be artists and take too long to make one piece. He also does not like degree shows where students show their work while trying to make fashion statements. "That can be pretentious. A piece of furniture should be something people can really use," he says.
Hurst may be confident and direct, but he is not pretentious. As I leave, he reminds me, "After all, I am only making furniture."

**Three Theories About Sleep**
People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.
The first and most popular theory says that sleep is important for our bodies. It suggests that we sleep to keep our bodies healthy. While we sleep, our bodies work to repair any damage from the day and to help us feel better.
The second theory focuses on learning. It says that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. Without sleep, we would not be able to learn effectively.
The third theory is about energy. It claims that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we are ready for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and does not follow the accepted norms of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most of us have our own quirks and odd habits. It could be a love for entering newspaper competitions, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to the press about various topics. Eccentricity shows our individuality. Inside us, there is often a struggle between two forces: individualism and conformity. Individualism wants us to be unique, while conformity wants us to fit in. For many, the desire to be accepted and liked is stronger than the desire to stand out.
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often come together. They form clubs and hold meetings to share their interests, which others might see as strange. The key word here is 'common.' They seek others who understand their oddities. Most of us feel a tension between wanting to fit in and wanting to be different. Even when we follow the crowd, we may feel the need to show our individuality. For example, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think," or a new acquaintance might declare, "You must take me as you find me."
Anyone can choose to embrace their individuality at any time. Many people succeed in their careers by doing just that. Bob Dylan, the American singer, once said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing, pursue it without giving up, and you will surprise many people." However, this strong expression of individuality is not the same as eccentricity, especially in the beginning. If a pop singer wears strange clothes just to get attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these behaviors until they become part of who they are, then they can be considered eccentric.
The most important aspect of eccentricity is that it is natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are. A true eccentric does not care much about what others think. They act according to who they are. This makes eccentrics different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, clever criminals, attention-seekers, and recluses. These people are aware of society and often react to it. Some want to impress others, while some want to escape from society. But eccentrics go about their lives without worrying about what others think.

**Natural Books**
We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have had the chance to meet some important figures in this field. One of the most significant is Barbara Ward, a small and delicate woman. She has been at the center of environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from different environmental movements into her own strong ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand these complex topics. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been *Only One Earth* or *Progress for a Small Planet*, but I believe *The Home of Man* is her most important work. It talks about the rapid growth of cities and covers the big themes she cared about. It is a powerful call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none compare to it.
**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read *Signals for Survival* by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of their droppings in the sun. This book wonderfully explains the interesting world of animal communication through words and pictures. After reading it, if you watch a gull colony, you will see how their chaotic activity is actually a well-organized social structure. You can identify which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a respected behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His work with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and interesting for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's simple yet effective paintings show how one gull can be aggressive while another is calm. This is the skill of a true naturalist.
**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is *My Family and Other Animals* by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband but also to an exciting career in conservation. It defined my love for the natural world. I was studying animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. After two years of challenges, opening this book made my day brighter. It beautifully connects animals, people, joy, and nature—a small world worth saving. Many people think humans are the worst because of the harm we have caused to other species. However, I remember Gerald as a boy in this book, seeing all living beings as a family, connected and inseparable. This is an important idea for everyone to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found *The Shell Bird Book* by James Fisher in my school library shortly after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially the 48 colorful bird illustrations by Eric Ennion. These images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start sketching what I saw. But *The Shell Bird Book* offered so much more. Along with the beautiful illustrations, it included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music, literature, and art. This wide range of information and exciting images encouraged me to appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. The book showed me that my emotional and creative connection to nature is just as important as a scientific one. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new opportunities for myself.

DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**
We asked five British publishers about how book reviews affect sales. Here is what they said.
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They are the first thing we look at in newspapers. A study showed that many people said they bought a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers often feel okay about bad reviews. They believe that any mention of a book can help sales, as readers want to see for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinions about a book since they are often the first to read it.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Book reviews today are better and more varied than they were 40 years ago. However, there is still a problem with not enough attention given to paperbacks, which most people read. Even though publishers may complain, they still need reviews to help promote books and authors. A good review from a trusted source can really boost sales, especially if there are several positive reviews.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing. Without them, we would struggle to promote our books. Most of our books are not by famous authors, so we rely on literary editors to give us space in their publications. Good reviews are much more valuable than ads because they show that the review is not influenced by money. Publishers often say they care more about the size of the review than its content. Good reviews can help launch a book and a writer's career, but they need support from other factors like recommendations and marketing.
**Publisher D**  
I wish I understood the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain! In the U.S., a single review in the New York Times can make or break a book. Here, bookshops often ignore reviews. Sometimes it takes many years of good reviews for people to notice a talented writer. Interestingly, some poorly reviewed books still sell very well. It’s unpredictable, but non-fiction reviews often focus more on the subject than the book itself.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews. But do they really sell books? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it didn’t sell well because people felt they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the name of the reviewer matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people paid attention. Now, it can also be the unexpected reviewer or the creativity of the review that encourages people to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**
The making of weathervanes is an old skill that dates back to ancient Egypt. Today, this craft is still alive in the workshop of Graham Smith. He is one of the few people in the country who makes hand-cut weathervanes. Graham's designs are unique and made to meet the specific needs of his customers. "This way, I can create a special personalized item," he explains. "Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a unique present that reflects the man's work or hobbies."
This is very different from the traditional cockerel, which is the most common design for weathervanes. The first weathervane Graham ever made was not a cockerel, but a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked the surprise gift he made for his wife and started asking him to make weathervanes for them. "I realized that there are endless possibilities for designs," he says. Graham decided to focus on his weathervane business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years when he and his wife, Liz, decided to change roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to take care of the children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he has no regrets about this change. "My previous job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic," he says. "I really enjoy the design part."
Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval for the design before he starts cutting it by hand. He also keeps many traditional designs in stock because they are just as popular as the unique ones. "People seem to like handmade items," Graham says. "They appreciate the chance to own something a little different."
Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People love the uniqueness, and I feel satisfied when I see a simple shape turn into something almost lifelike," he says. "For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction." He adds, "Now, with more people moving to the countryside, they want to add a special touch to their homes. This has helped crafts like mine."
Graham has become busier, supplying flat-packed weathervanes to customers around the world. Buyers from America and Denmark are particularly interested. "The price," he explains, "depends on how detailed the design is." His most recent request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

'Beginner Takes All'**
Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was already a very popular book. It is the first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, and it has made him a lot of money. Here, he talks about his inspiration and success.
At the beginning of the year, Nicholas Evans was having a tough time. A film project he had been working on, called *Life and Limb*, fell apart suddenly. He was worried because it had been two years since he had earned any money, and this film was his only hope to pay his bills. A sensible person in his situation would have found a job, perhaps returning to television. Instead, he made a surprising choice. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching for his first novel.
Although he acted on impulse, the idea for the story had been in his mind for a while. He had met a farrier on Dartmoor who told him about a gentle horse that suddenly became aggressive. The horse's owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These people were called "horse whisperers." This story inspired Evans. He started to research the topic, thinking about writing a screenplay since he was a filmmaker. However, after the failure of *Life and Limb*, he decided to write the story as a book.
During the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He later said, "It was a strange time. I was watching people, but I felt very alone and worried about my life. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt and unsure how to support my family."
By the end of August, he had returned home and written the first half of the book. He was still worried about money, so he showed his work to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent said it was "fine" and thought Evans could get $30,000 as an advance for the book. Evans needed more than that to pay off some of his debts. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and still had at least two months of work left. 
In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the novel, along with a 12-page summary of the rest, to seven UK publishers just before they went to the Frankfurt Book Fair. Soon, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. Evans was shocked and asked, "What?" The agent replied, "It's okay, I feel something good is happening."
What happened next is now part of publishing history. Within a week of competitive bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. Evans said, "We couldn't believe it; we were amazed. We never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don’t know how it got there." 
The major film studios also wanted the book. Evans's UK agent worked with an American agent, who called to say they could get $3 million for the film rights. They all laughed in disbelief. That October, Evans sat in his study while four famous filmmakers called one after another, asking to pay $3 million for an unfinished novel.
Evans shared this story while we drank coffee on his porch overlooking his garden. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's been like a fairy tale so far. I don’t want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very hard, and I don’t want to become just an employee of these people who have paid me so much money. I would hate to write a draft and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but we’ll hire someone else now.'"
He said he would stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new support for *Life and Limb*, but he was unsure if he wanted to make it anymore. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

'Young Masters'**
Bobby Fischer is facing challenges as he tries to return to chess. Chess is now more of a young man's game. After being away for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game, which was impressive, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. At 49 years old, he is out of practice and not in great shape. Spassky is even older. 
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, leading to a new era of professionalism. Now, winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player’s nerves and stamina are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high. Players use a chess clock to make sure they finish their moves in time, or they lose the game. Nowadays, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks. This increased pressure favors younger players. Over the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the last. Currently, eight of the ten highest-ranked players are under 30.
The way chess is played has also changed. Much of it now happens off the board. Players must prepare seriously before matches, especially because computers have changed the game. A small computer can store one million chess games and provide quick access to many games of an opponent. In recent matches, players have used large teams to find weaknesses in each other's strategies. The opening moves of a game are analyzed in great detail, and being well-prepared can be the key to winning.
Today, there are more top players than ever before. Many grandmasters compete for modest prizes around the world. Success in chess requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. A moment of distraction can lead to losing. The chess clock adds to the stress, especially during the final moments of a game when players have only seconds to make their moves. In these intense moments, players must act quickly and decisively.
At the highest level of chess, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress. However, one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess tournaments usually last 9-11 days, with games played every day. World championship matches can be even tougher. For example, the 1984 match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to be stopped after several months because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost about 10 kg during the match.
Can Bobby Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This makes his long absence from the game seem strange. But it also made him a legend. If he has returned for the money, he is in a good position, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. However, if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones interviews some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are on their way to success.
A. Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three well-received plays. He is now turning his first play, *Peaches*, into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as low as £30." The interesting thing about Nick is that before writing *Peaches*, he had never been to a play or read one. "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed," he explains. "It's set in a car. I probably wouldn't do that now because I know the problems it can cause. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he says. "Suddenly, I was with people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational setting. It was very inspiring."
B. Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tough tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even back in Bristol, he was practicing his comedy in clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor; I was always more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it really isn't. If you have courage and good material, it's wonderful to make people laugh." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but his partnership with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed I was imitating him," Simon admits.
C. Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became known to the public when he danced into their homes as the lead in the series *The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star*. The response was very positive, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says with a smile. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare and comfortable position, especially since he has just graduated. Looking back at Ciaran's early career, it's clear that such success was always possible. Encouraged by his mother, he went from leading roles in school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I was basically using acting to avoid doing homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided I wanted to pursue it because I had a talent and passion for it." Now, he is waiting for the praise to come in, but when asked about fame, he becomes serious. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about earning respect for doing good work."
D. Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single, *Chimera*, is released soon. "The record company's idea of good sales is different from mine," he says. "They want a big hit, but I just want two people to buy it and be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music industry ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I had been performing at student gigs for eight years and was starting to feel tired. I was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had connections at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have come at a better time. There were moments when I felt very down, and I was in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."
E. Poet and author Stephen Richards is 27 years old and has won more awards and honors than many people twice his age. He is already well-known in the poetry world, where he has been touring and giving readings several times a week for the past six years. His first novel, *Hidden*, will be published in March. "It's a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but lost interest in education later. "I chose not to go to university, but I became bored stuffing envelopes at a theater and decided I should go." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer; they thought I would just be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry receiving much praise, moving into novels is a brave step. "My poetry has a structure, and there's less chance of making big mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more words that could be bad. My main goal is to avoid just producing work without caring about quality."

A. Isabel, a 31-year-old art student, thinks she looks good in jeans but rarely wears them because she doesn’t want to attract the wrong people. She is looking for Mr. Right and worries that her knobbly knees might ruin her chances. However, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes in a lively style, using chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired," similar to the feel of an early silent film.
B. This story celebrates the rise and near-fall of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of a smart, shy child named Francis With. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station created by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, and announcers. The small-town setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing, taking readers back to the gentler times of the 1940s and 1950s, with its old stores and classic cars.
C. In the author's world, it is normal for a second husband to talk to his wife's first husband. When professor Richard Vaisey falls for a beautiful Russian poetess, he shares his feelings with his wife's ex-husband. The poetess writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she is also trying to get help for her wrongly imprisoned brother. However, the way the author untangles these issues is what makes the story interesting. E. This story, written by a great American author, is funny and touching. It follows Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about a past mistake and becomes a 'father' to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is slowly becoming an eccentric bachelor. The story explores many emotions and highlights the special bond Ian forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book that balances sadness and laughter perfectly.

**Volunteer Tourism**
Four academic writers discuss international voluntary work. 
A. It is difficult to say that volunteer tourists make a big difference in development. While they can help build homes or schools, they usually pay a large fee to participate in this work. This money, if given directly to a local community, could pay for more labor than the volunteer could provide. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often do not have the necessary skills or experience. Many studies question whether gap year volunteering is mainly about helping others or if young people are more interested in improving their own careers. However, these projects can help develop people who will act ethically in their future careers.
B. Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, and greater participation in global issues through civic organizations. It can also help build international social networks among everyday people. In this way, the overall benefits can be greater than the individual contributions, helping both volunteers and local communities. However, if volunteering is mostly done by wealthy individuals, it may only benefit them and not the communities that need help.
C. At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of charity that benefits wealthy Westerners more than the communities they aim to help. On the other hand, it can also provide valuable technical assistance for development. When done well, international volunteering can benefit both volunteers and the organizations they work with, while also allowing for the sharing of skills and cultural experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness of and commitment to fighting against poverty and injustice.
D. Volunteer tourism fits well with the growing trend of helping others. These small efforts to "make a difference" can seem positive, especially in a time when people are skeptical of big government and businesses. However, this approach can ignore the need for democratic government and reduce development to individual acts of charity, which may not truly help poor communities. While volunteering can be a good act, when it is promoted as sustainable development, it can misrepresent the real issues of global inequality and poverty faced by many in developing countries.

Sound the Alarm**
Stuart Harris reports
Many of us listen to the radio in the morning, and most of us need something to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, which included me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios that are currently available.
The 'dual alarm function' advertised with one model does not let you wake up with the buzzer, snooze for a while, and then get out of bed. The instruction booklet suggests using this function to set two different wake-up times: one for weekdays and one for weekends. But who really lives like that? Since this model costs about the same as the second one we tested, having a cassette player is a good deal—you can fall asleep to your favorite tapes and wake up without news. We all thought the radio quality was excellent, but we wished it was smaller. It is as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, "Any clock radio I buy must leave enough space on my bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. Also, I always book a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn’t go off."
This model was voted the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was "in love with it," even though the clock he tested "kept getting stuck at 16:00." I was impressed by the digital display, with its nice grey numbers on a soft green background. The wide snooze bar lets you tap it with your eyes closed. Unfortunately, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which caused problems when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if someone pulls the plug to use a hairdryer or vacuum cleaner; everyone liked this feature. However, we all found it difficult to set up, but once we figured it out, we felt "cool" and sophisticated.
Tom Granger called this model, which has a built-in lamp, "unbelievably tacky" because of how it is made. "You have to pull the light out of its socket to make it work, which makes me question the quality of the rest of it." He said he had to read the instruction booklet twice to get it to work; the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The light was hard to position; you could never read by it—it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea funny but agreed that the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine and made me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. Aimed at young people, with its bright colors and matching strap, it appealed to the child in Tom Granger and me. "I would choose this one because it stands out," he said. In fact, the traditional design of the controls made it the only one we could set up without reading the instruction booklet. Unfortunately, the alarm has a funny 20-minute error margin; the manual says, "the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time." Paul Bridges laughed at this idea, saying this model was "terribly fiddly" and "completely useless."
The simplest and cheapest of all the models tested scored points with Tom Granger because it "seemed very standard and took up little space," and it has old-fashioned dial tuning. "It's easier to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you’re never sure if you pressed all the buttons correctly, so you can’t be confident it will work." He agreed that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was a bit rough, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed that the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model definitely works; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Hedgehogs**
A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but none are found in America or Australia. All types of hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are attacked, which makes their spines stick out. This is a good way to protect themselves, but it works better if the hedgehog has many spines. Some hedgehogs that live in deserts have changed over time to carry less weight, so they have fewer spines. Because of this, they are more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up, using their rolling ability only as a last option. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, often hiding under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. In good conditions, some hedgehogs will stay awake all year.

Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**
Excelling in any sport is difficult, even for men, but women often face even more challenges. Training and competing take up a lot of time, leaving little room for a normal life, so sacrifices are necessary. Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and setting new records. Here, we talk to some amazing British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.
A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"It's a great feeling to fly through the air and land safely, but it can be scary. Sometimes I don’t feel well or it’s windy, and I can’t see well, but I just keep going. It’s hard to have a life outside of skiing because we train for ten months each year. I give up a lot of my social life and friends, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete on the same courses and are treated equally - it’s a young sport."
B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was amazing since I had never cycled before! I earn a good salary as a professional cyclist, and there are many opportunities for sponsorship. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks, not because I am a great cyclist. So, I focus on cycling instead of making money. I train for at least four hours every day on the bike, plus I do stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time it takes."
C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls to start because very few girls' schools offer it. Most girls don’t begin until they are 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Also, coaches often change every year, so the women’s team lacks stability. But I love it, and being fit is great, plus there is a good social life."
D. **Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not realizing how big it was! I felt trapped in Britain and wanted freedom. Each walk has been different. Walking across Australia was the hardest experience for me. I walked 50 miles a day with very little sleep and had many blisters on my feet. But I set a record! I had to because my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Some men think women are more likely to fail, so they see sponsoring us as a risk."
E. **Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when driving. When I do well, they often ignore me. Being a woman has its challenges. When I reach a corner, some men think, 'I have to beat her,' so I’ve had many tough moments! You need to be competitive and aggressive. It’s hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It’s great that more women are joining racing every year. For me, the excitement of saloon car racing is always trying to achieve a perfect lap."
F. **Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I either cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There is a lot of nervousness before a race, and when I compete, I really push myself. I often ask myself why I do this. The answers are: a) I feel happier when I stay fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t push myself, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the media, 90% of the articles focus on the men's events, and only 10% mention the women's events. The prize money is not as good either. But now we have formed an International Triathlon Women’s Commission to improve this."

The day I met Picasso, Richard Cork remembers how, as a 78-year-old student, he encountered one of the greatest artists of the century. Even from a distance, eating lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes, Picasso was easy to recognize. I was an 18-year-old student, traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old, unreliable van while waiting to start university. After running out of money, I found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of time drawing and was lucky to have a sketchbook with me when I met the famous artist.
Picasso was known to be a private person who usually worked alone in the hills. So, I was very surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Without my friend's encouragement, I would never have had the courage to walk over and ask for his signature. I was nervous as I introduced myself and offered my sketchbook, but to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added a lively drawing below. Picasso's art, even when abstract, often connected to real things. The lines he drew might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.
I thanked him and started a hesitant conversation. Since Picasso's English was worse than my French, an American woman at the table helped translate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak. But I managed to tell Picasso about my strong interest in art and my admiration for his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and proudly showed my friend what I had. But my friend noticed that the lunch was still going on. "Is that all?" he asked, looking at the signature. "Why don’t you go back and take advantage of this opportunity? You might not get another chance, and he probably wouldn’t mind if you drew his portrait."
With my sketchbook under my arm, I returned to Picasso's table. I thought it was best not to ask if I could draw his portrait, as he might say no and ruin the moment. So, I just stood by the table, leaned my pad against a screen, took out a crayon, and started to draw. When he noticed, Picasso smiled playfully and made it hard for me to draw. He acted out funny expressions, rolling his eyes, sticking out his tongue, and making strange shapes with his hands. It was like he was a clown. I felt like giving up, but his playful spirit challenged me to keep going. 
Eventually, Picasso relaxed and let me study him without distractions. I saw how strong and alert he looked, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed more like a fit 60-year-old than a man about to turn 84. His dark eyes were youthful and intense, and I tried to capture that in my drawing. He seemed a bit distant and alone, even with friends around him. His playful behavior hid a serious side. He let his friends talk while he sat quietly, focused on his own thoughts.
When the American lady told me that Picasso wanted to see my portrait, I felt embarrassed and said it wasn’t good enough. But Picasso insisted, and when I showed him my sketchbook, he nodded approvingly. Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In seconds, he drew a bearded face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with a single lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks.
I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. The American lady explained that he said I already had his signature. So, there were limits to his generosity! Still, I look back now and feel very lucky. Meeting Picasso and receiving his attention meant a lot to me.

'Shopping Tricks'**
Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Here are some tricks that shops use to make you spend more money.
A. **Freshness First**  
Supermarkets know that customers like fresh food. They often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store or have displays of house plants to create a fresh feeling. They might also have a bakery that fills the store with the smell of fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, are chosen because they remind people of fresh produce. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, is not fresh.
B. **Smart Product Placement**  
Where products are placed in the store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computers to find out which areas of the store customers visit the most. In these areas, they place products that have high prices or sell quickly. Items at eye level are more likely to be bought, so manufacturers want their products on those shelves. Special offer bins attract customers looking for bargains. Another strategy is to place related items together, like desserts near ice cream.
C. **Spreading Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place low-priced items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, customers have to walk past more expensive items to get to them. Chain stores also place popular products away from the entrance, hoping that loyal customers will search for them and see other tempting items along the way.
D. **Less is More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from the idea of stacking many items to sell them cheaply. Instead, they display fewer items, making them seem more exclusive. Their success comes from good store design as well as stylish clothing.
E. **Total Costs Matter**  
Food shoppers often pay more attention to the total cost of their shopping than to the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-priced essentials with higher-priced items. They sometimes sell certain low-priced items at a loss to attract customers, a strategy known as 'loss leaders.' They also get discounts from manufacturers by buying in large quantities or giving products good display space.
F. **The Price Tag**  
Customers tend to buy fewer items in chain stores and notice individual prices more. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This pricing strategy also helps reduce theft, as staff must ring up sales to give change.
G. **Lighting Matters**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores aim for lighting that looks like natural daylight so customers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lighting to make fresh foods look more appealing.
H. **Guiding Shoppers**  
Many chain stores use different types of flooring to guide customers through the store. One pattern is for walking paths, and another is for sales areas. This strategy, called the 'Yellow Brick Road,' encourages shoppers to follow certain routes. For example, Marks and Spencer use wood or marble for paths to lead customers to more inviting carpeted sales areas.
I. **In-Store Promotions**  
As you enter a supermarket, you might see large, colorful pictures of delicious food, which can make you hungry if you haven't eaten. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing 'video trolleys' that show ads for products while you shop. These trolleys aim to attract impulse buyers and can increase sales by about 30 percent.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**
Mountaineer Chris Bonnington (58) is famous for reaching the top of Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston (53) started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England. 
Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while I was working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin to ask for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sail. I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first time on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to the shore to practice climbing. The route was quite hard, but I was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. 
After a while, we reached a big drop. I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. He hadn’t, so I showed him how to do it. When I finished, Robin politely asked if he could go down the way he used to on his boat. He was used to using his arms, but I wanted him to use his legs. I was not very happy about it, but he lowered himself down safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I built a strong friendship. His idea to combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural next step after our journey to Skye. 
I was very impressed by Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin always asked for everyone’s opinion first. Most of the time, people were too afraid to give him advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making. To be honest, I found sailing difficult and boring. The moments of crisis were easy to handle because of the adrenaline, but spending day after day in the middle of the sea was hard for me. I prefer being on land and am not very handy. Robin, on the other hand, is a natural sailor and enjoyed fixing the engine or repairing the toilet. I realized that Robin didn’t really need my help, which made me feel a bit useless at times. 
The crew was also very close together: six people on a 32-foot yacht that was meant for four. When you are on a mountain expedition, you can get away from each other. When we reached Greenland and it was my turn to lead the expedition, I found it hard to take responsibility for Robin’s safety. There were many times when, if Robin had fallen, he could have pulled me down with him. I had to be careful about that. I underestimated how hard climbing the Cathedral, Greenland’s highest mountain, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. 
The first time we tried to reach the top, we were climbing for 24 hours. On the way down, we were so tired that we almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin worked very hard, but he completely trusted me and just followed. When it became too difficult and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted it. I also knew that Robin was worried about the boat: whether we could get it through the ice and if it was okay. Still, he wanted to try climbing the mountain again. 
The only time we almost had a problem in our relationship was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns to keep watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me. He thought he could handle it alone. The night before, I had almost fallen asleep. I felt that he didn’t trust me, which made me feel insecure, and I told him so. Robin quickly reassured me that I was wrong to think that. While we enjoyed the trip to Skye, we didn’t really get to know each other until the end of the Greenland expedition. I found that beneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**
Apples have been part of human life for thousands of years, coming in many colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this important part of our history.
**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
People have been eating apples since ancient times. In neolithic Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. About 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these areas, early humans even stored dried apple halves for winter. These apples were wild crab apples, small and not like the apples we eat today.
**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans, and this knowledge spread to Britain. The Romans brought some apple varieties, but many did not grow well in Britain. After the Norman Conquest, new apple varieties became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new types of apples, which are the ancestors of many Western apples today.
**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
In the thirteenth century, several apple types became common in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, known for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a popular cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century. However, due to droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, fewer apples were produced, and more were imported. This changed in the sixteenth century when King Henry VIII sent his fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple growing. Harris returned with many new apple varieties, including the famous Pippins, and started the first modern orchard in Kent.
**Settler Treasures (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them. Captain Bligh of the Bounty brought apples to Australia, and Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa. The Pilgrim Fathers carried them to America. In North America, the famous apple planter was John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed'. Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. He was seen as a kind man and became the subject of many stories.
**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt in Iowa found a new apple tree growing from the roots of a dead tree. He named the apple 'Hawkey'. When a judge tasted it at a fruit show, he exclaimed, "Delicious!" In 1895, the apple was sold as 'Delicious' and became one of the most popular apples in the world.
**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She was the daughter of convicts and worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales. Known as 'Granny Smith', she took care of her family's farm. In 1868, she found a small tree growing from discarded fruit. She moved it, and soon she was harvesting green apples that became famous worldwide. When asked about the tree, she said, "It's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish," referring to both the apple and her own background.
**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world, from India to Africa. However, most apples come from just a few varieties, chosen for their appearance and ability to travel rather than their taste. This lack of variety is a problem, as it reduces the diversity of apples. While some gardeners in the UK have kept old apple varieties alive, many apples in the US have been lost over the past century. However, consumers are starting to want more variety. We cannot rely only on amateur gardeners to save apple diversity; we must work to protect and value the natural variety of apples for everyone's benefit.
